SENT.plain: Diamond-Blackfan anemia (DBA) is a rare disorder characterized by congenital pure red cell aplasia
Mutations in ribosomal protein S19 (RPS19) have been identified in 25% of DBA patients
More recently, mutations in other ribosomal protein genes, namely RPS7, RPS15, RPS24, RPS17, RPS27A, RPL35a, RPL36, RPL11, and RPL5, have also been found in patients with DBA
Approximately 30-40% of affected patients have various associated physical anomalies, mostly craniofacial and at the extremities, but also cardiac or urogenital malformations
Anomalies of the urogenital tract in DBA patients comprise changes in the kidney (dysplasia, agenesis, duplication, horseshoe kidney) and genitalia (hypospadias)
To date, disorders of sex development (DSD) have only been described once in association with DBA
We report here four DBA patients who exhibited DSD
